current_subquestions: Q1: Identify the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides.
Q2: Determine the color of the surrounding cells.
Q3: Change the color of the identified cells to the color determined in Q2.
Q4: Repeat the process for all colors present in the grid.
new_subanswers_ys:
A1: To identify the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides, we can iterate through each cell in the grid. For each cell, we check its top, bottom, left, and right neighbors. If all four neighbors have the same color as the current cell, we mark this cell as surrounded. 
A2: To determine the color of the surrounding cells, we can simply check the color of any one of the neighboring cells that we have already confirmed to be the same color. This can be done by accessing the value of the cell in the grid. For example, if we are checking the cell at position (i, j), we can check the color of the top neighbor at position (i-1, j).
A3: To change the color of the identified cells, we can simply assign the new color to the cell in the grid. For example, if we are changing the color of the cell at position (i, j) to the color c, we can do this by setting grid[i][j] = c.
A4: To repeat the process for all colors present in the grid, we can first identify all unique colors present in the grid. This can be done by iterating through each cell in the grid and adding its color to a set, which automatically removes duplicates. Then, for each unique color, we repeat the process described in Q1-Q3.
